templates.name: Basic Linux Metrics
templates.description:
This is an official Linux template. It requires Zabbix agent 7.0 or newer.

Notes on filesystem (FS) discovery:
- The ext4/3/2 filesystem reserves space for privileged usage, typically set at 5% by default.
- BTRFS allocates a default of 10% of the volume for its own needs.
- To mitigate potential disasters, FS usage triggers are based on the maximum available space.
  - Utilization formula: 'pused = 100 - 100 * (available / total - free + available)'
- The FS utilization chart, derived from graph prototypes, reflects FS reserved space as the difference between used and available space from the total volume.

You can discuss this template or leave feedback on our forum https://www.zabbix.com/forum/zabbix-suggestions-and-feedback/387225-discussion-thread-for-official-zabbix-template-for-linux

Generated by official Zabbix template tool "Templator"

items.name: Host name of Zabbix agent running
Zabbix agent ping
items.description: The agent always returns "1" for this item. May be used in combination with `nodata()` for the availability check.

items.name: Maximum number of processes
items.description: May be increased by using the `sysctl` utility or modifying the file `/etc/sysctl.conf`.

triggers.name: Configured max number of processes is too low
triggers.event_name: Configured max number of processes is too low (< {$KERNEL.MAXPROC.MIN})

items.name: Load average (1m avg)
items.description: Calculated as the system CPU load divided by the number of CPU cores.

items.name: Load average (5m avg)
items.description: Calculated as the system CPU load divided by the number of CPU cores.

items.name: Load average (15m avg)
items.description: Calculated as the system CPU load divided by the number of CPU cores.

items.name: CPU utilization
items.description: CPU utilization expressed in %.

triggers.name: High CPU utilization
triggers.description: CPU utilization is too high. The system might be slow to respond.

dependencies.name: Load average is too high

items.name: CPU idle time
items.description: Time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

items.name: System name
items.description: The host name of the system.

triggers.expression: change(/Basic Linux Metrics/system.hostname) and length(last(/Basic Linux Metrics/system.hostname))>0
triggers.name: System name has changed
triggers.description: The name of the system has changed. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

items.name: System local time
items.description: The local system time of the host.

triggers.name: System time is out of sync
triggers.event_name: System time is out of sync (diff with Zabbix server > {$SYSTEM.FUZZYTIME.MAX})
triggers.description: The host's system time is different from Zabbix server time.

items.name: Free swap space
items.description: The free space of the swap volume/file expressed in bytes.

items.name: Free swap space in %
items.description: The free space of the swap volume/file expressed in %.

items.name: Total swap space
items.description: The total space of the swap volume/file expressed in bytes.

items.name: System description
items.description: The information as normally returned by `uname -a`.

items.name: System uptime
items.description: The system uptime expressed in the following format: "N days, hh:mm:ss".

triggers.name: {HOST.NAME} has been restarted
triggers.description: The host uptime is less than 10 minutes.

dependencies.name: System name has changed
dependencies.expression: change(/Basic Linux Metrics/system.hostname) and length(last(/Basic Linux Metrics/system.hostname))>0

items.name: Get filesystems
items.description: The `vfs.fs.get` key acquires raw information set about the filesystems. Later to be extracted by preprocessing in dependent items.

items.name: Available memory
items.description:
The available memory:
- in Linux = free + buffers + cache;
- on other platforms calculation may vary.

See also Appendixes in Zabbix Documentation about parameters of the `vm.memory.size` item.

items.name: Available memory in %
items.description: The available memory as percentage of the total. See also Appendixes in Zabbix Documentation about parameters of the `vm.memory.size` item.

items.name: Total memory
items.description: Total memory expressed in bytes.

items.name: Memory utilization
items.description: The percentage of used memory is calculated as `100-pavailable`.

triggers.name: High memory utilization
triggers.description: The system is running out of free memory.

triggers.name: Warning memory utilization
triggers.description: The system is running out of free memory.

items.name: Zabbix agent availability
items.description: Used for monitoring the availability status of the agent.

triggers.name: Zabbix agent is not available
triggers.description: For passive agents only, host availability is used with `{$AGENT.TIMEOUT}` as a time threshold.

trigger_prototypes.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])=2 and (last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#1)<>last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#2))
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
trigger_prototypes.description:
This trigger expression works as follows:
1. It can be triggered if the operations status is down.
2. `{$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1` - a user can redefine the context macro to "0", marking this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down.
3. `last(/TEMPLATE_NAME/METRIC,#1)<>last(/TEMPLATE_NAME/METRIC,#2)` - the trigger fires only if the operational status was up to (1) sometime before (so, does not fire for "eternal off" interfaces.)

WARNING: if closed manually - it will not fire again on the next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Speed
item_prototypes.description:
It indicates the latest or current speed value of the interface. The value is an integer representing the link speed expressed in bits/sec.
This attribute is only valid for the interfaces that implement the ethtool `get_link_ksettings` method (mostly Ethernet).

Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Interface type
item_prototypes.description:
It indicates the interface protocol type as a decimal value.
See `include/uapi/linux/if_arp.h` for all possible values.
Reference: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-class-net

trigger_prototypes.expression:
change(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])<0 and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])>0
and
(last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"])=6 or last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/type"])=1)
and
(last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])<>2)
trigger_prototypes.recovery_expression:
(change(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])>0 and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"],#2)>0) or
(last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])=2)
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototypes.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Acknowledge to close the problem manually.

dependencies.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
dependencies.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])=2 and (last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#1)<>last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#2))

trigger_prototypes.expression:
(avg(/Basic Linux Metrics/net.if.in["{#IFNAME}"],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"]) or
avg(/Basic Linux Metrics/net.if.out["{#IFNAME}"],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])) and
last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])>0
trigger_prototypes.recovery_expression:
avg(/Basic Linux Metrics/net.if.in["{#IFNAME}"],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"]) and
avg(/Basic Linux Metrics/net.if.out["{#IFNAME}"],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/speed"])
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: High bandwidth usage
trigger_prototypes.description: The utilization of the network interface is close to its estimated maximum bandwidth.

dependencies.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
dependencies.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])=2 and (last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#1)<>last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#2))

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: High error rate
trigger_prototypes.description: It recovers when it is below 80% of the `{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}` threshold.

dependencies.name: Interface {#IFNAME}: Link down
dependencies.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"])=2 and (last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#1)<>last(/Basic Linux Metrics/vfs.file.contents["/sys/class/net/{#IFNAME}/operstate"],#2))

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk average queue size (avgqu-sz)
item_prototypes.description: The current average disk queue; the number of requests outstanding on the disk while the performance data is being collected.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read request avg waiting time (r_await)
item_prototypes.description: This formula contains two Boolean expressions that evaluate to 1 or 0 in order to set the calculated metric to zero and to avoid the exception - division by zero.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototypes.description: r/s (read operations per second) - the number (after merges) of read requests completed per second for the device.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read time (rate)
item_prototypes.description: The rate of total read time counter; used in `r_await` calculation.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization
item_prototypes.description: The percentage of elapsed time during which the selected disk drive was busy while servicing read or write requests.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write request avg waiting time (w_await)
item_prototypes.description: This formula contains two Boolean expressions that evaluate to 1 or 0 in order to set the calculated metric to zero and to avoid the exception - division by zero.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototypes.description: w/s (write operations per second) - the number (after merges) of write requests completed per second for the device.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write time (rate)
item_prototypes.description: The rate of total write time counter; used in `w_await` calculation.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Get stats
item_prototypes.description: The contents of get `/sys/block/{#DEVNAME}/stat` to get the disk statistics.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read/write request responses are too high
trigger_prototypes.event_name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read/write request responses are too high (read > {$VFS.DEV.READ.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} ms for 15m or write > {$VFS.DEV.WRITE.AWAIT.WARN:"{#DEVNAME}"} ms for 15m)
trigger_prototypes.description: This trigger might indicate the disk `{#DEVNAME}` saturation.

discovery_rules.name: Mounted filesystem discovery
discovery_rules.description: The discovery of mounted filesystems with different types.

trigger_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Running out of free inodes
trigger_prototypes.description: Disk writing may fail if index nodes are exhausted, leading to error messages like "No space left on device" or "Disk is full", despite available free space.

trigger_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Running out of free inodes
trigger_prototypes.event_name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description: Disk writing may fail if index nodes are exhausted, leading to error messages like "No space left on device" or "Disk is full", despite available free space.

dependencies.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Running out of free inodes

item_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Space: Available
item_prototypes.description: Available storage space expressed in bytes.

item_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Space: Used, in %
item_prototypes.description: Calculated as the percentage of currently used space compared to the maximum available space.

trigger_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Space is critically low
trigger_prototypes.event_name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%, total {{?last(//vfs.fs.dependent.size[{#FSNAME},total])/1024/1024/1024}.fmtnum(1)}GB)
trigger_prototypes.description:
The volume's space usage exceeds the `{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%` limit.
The trigger expression is based on the current used and maximum available spaces.
Event name represents the total volume space, which can differ from the maximum available space, depending on the filesystem type.

trigger_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Space is low
trigger_prototypes.description:
The volume's space usage exceeds the `{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%` limit.
The trigger expression is based on the current used and maximum available spaces.
Event name represents the total volume space, which can differ from the maximum available space, depending on the filesystem type.

item_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Option: Read-only
item_prototypes.description: The filesystem is mounted as read-only. It is available only for Zabbix agents 6.4 and higher.

trigger_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSNAME}]: Filesystem has become read-only
trigger_prototypes.description: The filesystem has become read-only, possibly due to an I/O error. Available only for Zabbix agents 6.4 and higher.

graph_prototypes.name: FS [{#FSTYPE}({#FSNAME})]: Space usage graph, in % (relative to max available)
FS [{#FSTYPE}({#FSNAME})]: Space utilization chart (relative to total)

overrides.name: Skip metadata collection for dynamic FS

macros.description: Timeout after which agent is considered unavailable. Works only for agents reachable from Zabbix server/proxy (passive mode).
Critical threshold of CPU utilization expressed in %.
Warning threshold of error packet rate. Can be used with interface name as context.
Used as a threshold in the interface utilization trigger.
Link status trigger will be fired only for interfaces where the context macro equals "1".
The CPU load per core is considered sustainable. If necessary, it can be tuned.
Used as a threshold in the available memory trigger.
Used as a threshold in the memory utilization trigger.
Used as a threshold in the memory utilization trigger.
Used for network interface discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Filters out `loopbacks`, `nulls`, docker `veth` links and `docker0` bridge by default.
The warning threshold of the minimum free swap.
The upper threshold for difference of system time.
The lower threshold for difference of system time. Used in recovery expression to avoid trigger flapping.
Used for block device discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Used for block device discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
The average response time (in ms) of disk read before the trigger fires.
The average response time (in ms) of disk write before the trigger fires.
Used for filesystem discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Used for filesystem discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Used for filesystem discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
Used for filesystem discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level.
The critical threshold of the filesystem metadata utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem metadata utilization.
The critical threshold of the filesystem utilization.
The warning threshold of the filesystem utilization.

value.name: FS [{#FSTYPE}({#FSNAME})]: Space utilization chart (relative to total)

triggers.name: Getting closer to process limit
triggers.event_name: Getting closer to process limit (over 80% used)

triggers.expression: max(/Basic Linux Metrics/system.swap.size[,pfree],5m)<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and last(/Basic Linux Metrics/system.swap.size[,total])>0
triggers.name: High swap space usage
triggers.event_name: High swap space usage (less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
triggers.description: If there is no swap configured, this trigger is ignored.

triggers.name: Load average is too high
triggers.event_name: Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: The load average per CPU is too high. The system may be slow to respond.
